Diagnosis
	1. Merkel cell carcinoma right forearm
	Date of diagnosis
	January 2024

	Treatment aim
	Palliative

	Summary of completed treatment and relevant dates

	Surgery
	15 Jan 2024 Wide local excision and axillary node dissection

	Chemotherapy
	1 Feb 2024 - 15 Mar 2024 Carboplatin/Etoposide

	Clinical studies
	Not eligible for current immunotherapy trials due to autoimmune disease

	Current disease status
	Progressive disease with new pulmonary metastases

	Current issues
	Breathlessness, right-sided chest pain, fatigue

	Summary of consultation
	I reviewed [redacted name] today, who attended with her husband. Unfortunately, her recent CT scan has shown progression of disease with multiple new pulmonary metastases, the largest measuring 3.2cm in the right lower lobe. This correlates with her increasing breathlessness and right-sided chest pain over the past three weeks.

She completed three cycles of carboplatin/etoposide in March 2024, but developed significant neutropenic sepsis requiring ICU admission after the final cycle. Her initial response was good with complete resolution of the primary site and reduction in axillary nodes, but she has now developed progressive disease within 6 weeks of completing chemotherapy.

Given her recent severe toxicity with chemotherapy and her underlying rheumatoid arthritis, we have had a detailed discussion about treatment options. We agreed to proceed with palliative radiotherapy to the largest symptomatic lung lesion, with a view to considering second-line chemotherapy with dose reduction once she has recovered further strength.

	Further investigations
	Urgent CT-planning scan booked for tomorrow

	Medication prescribed
	Oxycodone 5mg PRN for chest pain

	Follow up
	Urgent radiotherapy planning tomorrow
Review in 2 weeks after completion of radiotherapy

	Required GP actions
	Please monitor renal function and FBC weekly
Please refer to district nurses for support with increasing care needs

	Summary of information given to patient
	Detailed discussion about disease progression and treatment options. Patient understands palliative intent of ongoing care. Written information provided about palliative radiotherapy.
